1.titleArabic:
،*الفاتحة* 

أم الكتاب، أم القرآن، السبع المثاني، الحمد، الشفاء، سورة الصلاة، الأساس
1.titleRomanization:
*Al-Fatiha* 

*aka*: Umm ul-Kitab, Umm ul-Qur'an, As-Sab' ul-Mathani, Al-Hamd, 
Ash-Shifa', Surat As-Salah, Al-'Asas
1.titleEnglish:
*The Opening* 

*aka:* Mother of the Book, Mother of the Koran, The Oft-Recited Seven, 
Praise, The Cure, Chapter of the Prayer, The Foundation
1.topics:
- The fundamental principles of the Qur'an in a condensed form.[8]
   - A prayer to God which encompasses all needs.

2.revelationPhase:
Medina phase (622 - 632 AD). Except 281 from Mina at the time of the Last 
Hajj
2.topics:
- Believers, disbelievers, and hypocrites
   - Creation of Adam and the fall
   - The errors committed by the Children of Israel, past and present[8]
   - Abraham and Ishmael building the Kaaba
   - Acts of worship (Qibla, fasting in Ramadan, Hajj, Charity)
   - Legal ordinances and social relations (dietary restrictions, warfare, 
   intoxicants and gambling, orphans, marriage and divorce, usury, economic 
   contracts, etc)[8]
   - The story about Joshua, Saul, David, and Goliath
   - Ayatul Kursi (v. 255)[9]
   - God's power to give and take life

3.topics:
- The oneness of God
   - The interpretation of the Qur'an
   - Births of Mary, John, and Jesus
   - Miracles of Jesus and relationship with the apostles
   - The People of the Book
   - The Battle of Uhud and the hypocrites (3 AH)[8]
   - Those who remember God and call upon Him

4.topics:
- Unity of the human race and the mutual obligations of men and women 
   towards one another (v. 1) [8]
   - Questions related to family life (including marriage and inheritance) 
   and emphasis on justice[8]
   - Rights of women[8]
   - Peace and war and the hypocrites[8]
   - People of the Book

5.revelationPhase: Medina phase (622 - 632 AD). Except 3, revealed at Arafat on Last Hajj
5.topics:
- A series of ritual and legal ordinances (Dietary restrictions, 
   intermarriage, Wudu, Hajj, etc)[8]
   - Extensive discussion of The People of the Book

6.revelationPhase:
Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 20, 23, 91, 93, 114, 151, 152, 
153, from Medina
6.topics:
- Oneness and uniqueness of God[8]
   - Refutation of the polytheists
   - Refutation of Pre-Islamic superstitions concerning animals, then 
   countered with Islamic values [8]

7.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 163-170, from Medina
7.topics:
- The mission of the prophets[8]
   - Lessons from the story of Satan tempting Adam and about modesty [8]
   - Dialogue between the people in Heaven and Hell
   - Stories of Noah, Hud, Saleh, Lot, and Jethro [8]
   - Moses and the salvation of the Israelites and their deviation 
   thereafter
   - Muhammad, the unlettered prophet mentioned in the Torah and Gospel
   - Allah's Covenant with humanity (v. 172) [10]
   - What happens to those who discard Allah’s message (v. 175) [8]

8.revelationPhase: Medina phase (622 - 632 AD). Except 30-36 from Mecca
8.topics:
- The Battle of Badr (2 A.H.) and rules of war [8]
   - Doctrine of sacrifice through action [8]

9.revelationPhase: Medina phase (622 - 632 AD). Except last two verses from Mecca
9.topics:
- How and why to fight the unbelievers
   - Criticism of corrupt religious leaders
   - Trials during wartime and the fitna of the hypocrites
   - Who can receive charity
   - Loyalty and obedience to God and his Prophet

10.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 40, 94, 95, 96, from Medina
10.topics:
- Divine origin of the Qur'an and that Muhammad did not fabricate it (v. 
   15-17, 37-38, 94) [8]
   - Response to challenges made by the Meccan polytheists
   - All creatures will return to God
   - Futility of conjecture (Polytheism is dismissed as conjecture)
   - How different people respond to guidance: 
      - Noah's people reject guidance altogether
      - Pharaoh believes when it is too late
      - Jonah's people believed and were saved

11.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 12, 17, 114, from Medina
11.topics:
- Continuation of refutation of the polytheists
   - Stories of past prophets' struggles to comfort and encourage the 
   Prophet and the believers: 
      - The stories of Noah, Hud, Saleh, angels bringing Abraham good news 
      of Isaac, the story of Lot, the story of Jethro, and quick mention of 
      Moses [8]

12.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 1, 2, 3, 7, from Medina
12.topics:
- The story of Joseph (an illustration of God’s unfathomable direction 
   of men’s affairs; a comfort to the Prophet and believers in the Year of 
   Sadness) [8]

13.topics:
- God's majesty reflected in the natural wonders of creation
   - Revelation and the concequences of accepting or rejecting it [8]

14.revelationPhase: Late Mecca phase (620 - 622 AD). Except 28, 29, from Medina
14.topics:
- Revelation to lead mankind from darkness to light[8]
   - Gratitude and ingratitude to God's blessings
   - Patience and trust in God
   - The severity of God's punishments
   - Abraham's prayers

15.titleEnglish: *The City of Stone* or *The Rocky Plain*
15.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 87, from Medina
15.topics:
- Inevitability of God's decree
   - Responses to challenges of the polytheists
   - Creation of Adam and Iblis's refusal to bow
   - Angels bring Abraham good news of Isaac and the story of Lot
   - Mention of Midian and Thamud
   - Reminder to the Prophet to have forbearance and resolution

16.revelationPhase: Late Mecca phase (620 - 622 AD). Except the last three verses from Medina
16.topics:
- The many wonders of creation and God's blessings on man [8]
   - Rejection of polytheism and warnings to the polytheists
   - Importance of uprightness and keeping oaths

17.titleEnglish:
*The Night Journey* 

*aka*: The Children of Israel, Glory
17.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 26, 32, 33, 57, 73-80, from Medina
17.topics:
- Muhammad’s mystic night journey from Mecca to Jerusalem.[8]
   - The children of Israel (v. 2-8, 101-104) [8]

18.revelationPhase: Late Mecca phase (620 - 622 AD). Except 28, 83-101, from Medina
18.topics:
- A series of parables or allegories on the theme of faith in God versus 
   excessive attachment to the life of this world. Including:[8] 
      - The men of the cave (v. 13-20) [8]
      - The rich man and the poor man (v. 32-44) [8]
      - Moses and the unnamed sage (v. 60-82) [8]
      - The allegory of Dhul-Qarnayn (v. 83-98) [8]

19.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 58 and 71, from Medina
19.topics:
- The story of Zechariah and his son John, the precursor of Jesus (v. 
   2-15) [8]
   - The story of Mary and Jesus (v. 16-37) [8]

20.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 130 and 131, from Medina
20.topics:
- The guidance offered by God through His prophets[8]
   - The fundamental truths inherent in all revealed religions are identical
   [8] 
      - The story of Moses (v. 9-98) [8]

21.topics:
- The oneness, uniqueness and transcendence of God[8]
   - The continuity and intrinsic unity of all divine revelation[8] 
      - Stories of the prophets of old (v. 48-91) [8]
      - The believers of all faiths belong to one single community (v. 92) 
      [8]

22.revelationPhase: Medina phase (622 - 632 AD). Except 52-55, revealed between Mecca and Medina
22.topics:
- The Mecca pilgrimage and some of the rituals connected with it (v. 
   25-38) [8]

23.topics:
- True faith[8]
   - The evidence of the existence of an almighty Creator, and man’s 
   ultimate responsibility before Him[8]
   - The unity of all religious communities, broken by man’s egotism, greed 
   and striving after power (v. 52-53) [8]
   - The impossibility to believe in God, without believing in life after 
   death[8]

24.topics:
- Mutual relations and ethical rules between men and women[8]
   - The mystic parable of the ‘light of God’ (*"Verse of Light"*). (v. 35) 
   [8]

25.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 68-70, from Medina
25.topics:
- The purpose of every divine revelation is to provide a stable 
   criterion of true and false[8]
   - The humanness of every apostle sent by God to man (v. 20) [8]
   - Divine revelation belongs to God’s creative activity[8]

26.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 197 and 224-227, from Medina
26.topics:
- Man’s weakness, which causes him to reject God’s message, and worship 
   power and wealth, etc.[8]

27.topics: - The legend of King Solomon and theQueen of Sheba[8]

28.revelationPhase:
Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 52-55 from Medina and 85 from 
Juhfa at the time of the Hijra
28.topics: - Human aspects of the life of Moses[8]

29.revelationPhase:
Late Mecca phase (620 - 622 AD). 

Except 1-11, from Medina
29.topics:
- The parable of ‘the spider house’, a symbol of false beliefs that are 
   destined to be blown away by the winds of truth (v. 41) [8]

30.revelationPhase:
Late Mecca phase (620 - 622 AD). 

Except 17, from Medina
30.topics:
- Predictions of the near victory of the Byzantines [over the Persians] 
   and the Battle of Badr (2 A.H.) (v. 1-7) [8]
   - God’s ability to resurrect the dead at the end of time, and the 
   people’s ignorance of this[8]

31.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 27-29, from Medina
31.topics:
- The story of Luqman, a legendary sage, counselling his son (v. 12-19) 
   [8]

32.titleEnglish:
*Prostration* 

*aka*: The Beds, Alif Lam Meem Revelation
32.revelationPhase: Late Mecca phase (620 - 622 AD). Except 16-20, from Medina
32.topics:
- God's creation[11]
   - God's revelation and man's acceptance or denial[11]
   - The Day of Judgement[11]

33.topics:
- The War of the Confederates (5 A.H.) (v. 9-27) [8]
   - The relationship between Muhammad and his family[8]

34.topics:
- The insignificance of the knowledge accessible to man (v. 9) [8]
   - The story of the people of Sheba, as an example of the impermanence of 
   human power, wealth and glory (v. 15-20) [8]
   - Always be conscious of God (v. 46) [8]

35.topics:
- God’s power to create and resurrect[8]
   - God’s revelation of His will through His prophets[8]

36.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 45, from Medina
36.topics:
- Man’s moral responsibility, resurrection and God’s judgment.[8]
   - To be recited over the dying and in the prayers of the dead.[8]

37.topics:
- Resurrection and the certainty that all human beings will have to 
   answer before God.[8]
   - Man’s constant need of prophetic guidance.[8] 
      - Stories of earlier prophets. (v. 75-148) [8]

38.topics:
- Divine guidance and its rejection by those who are lost in fast pride.
   [8]

39.topics:
- The evidence of the existence and oneness of God in all manifestations 
   of nature.[8]
   - God forgives all sins to him who repents before his death.[8]
   - Allegories of the Last Hour and the Day of Judgment.[8]

40.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 56, 57, from Medina
40.topics:
- Man’s false pride, worship of false values (wealth, power etc.) and 
   his denial of divine guidance.[8] 
      - Stories of earlier prophets.[8]

41.titleEnglish:
*Expounded* 

*aka*: Ha Meem Prostration, Lamps, Means of Sustenance
41.topics: - Man’s acceptance or rejection of divine revelation.[8]

42.revelationPhase: Late Mecca phase (620 - 622 AD). Except 23, 24, 25, 27, from Medina
42.topics:
- God is undefinable and unfathomable. (v. 11, 16) [8]
   - All prophets taught the oneness of God, so all believers of all 
   ‘denominations’ should see themselves as ‘one single community’. (v. 13, 
   15) [8]
   - The law of cause and effect: In the life to come man will only harvest 
   ‘what his own hands have wrought’ in this world.[8]

43.revelationPhase: Late Mecca phase (620 - 622 AD). Except 54, from Medina
43.topics:
- To equal anyone or anything with God is spiritually destructive and 
   logically unacceptable.[8]
   - People’s blind adherence to the faith of their forefathers. (v. 22-23) 
   [8]

44.topics: - Through revelation worldly pride is eventually brought to naught.[11]

45.revelationPhase: Late Mecca phase (620 - 622 AD). Except 14, from Medina
45.topics:
- The humility with which all human beings will face their final 
   judgment on resurrection. (v. 28) [8]

46.revelationPhase: Late Mecca phase (620 - 622 AD). Except 10, 15, 35, from Medina

47.revelationPhase: Medina phase (622 - 632 AD). Except 13, revealed during Muhammad's Hijrah

48.revelationPhase: Medina phase (622 - 632 AD).Revealed while returning from Hudaybiyya

49.topics:
- Social ethics[8] 
      - Reverence to Muhammad and the righteous leaders after him.[8]
      - The brotherhood of all believers and all mankind. (v. 10, 13) [8]
      - The difference between true faith and outward observance of 
      religious formalities. (v. 14 ff.) [8]

50.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 38, from Medina
50.topics:
- Death and resurrection.[8]
   - God is closer to man than his neck-vein. (v. 16)[11]

53.revelationPhase: Early Mecca phase (610-618 AD). Except 32, from Medina
53.topics:
- Muhammad’s experience of an ascension to heaven (Mi’raj, including his 
   vision of the Sidrat al-Muntaha, the Lote-Tree of the Extremity). (v. 
   13-18) [8]

54.titleEnglish:
*The Moon* 

*aka*: The Hour Has Drawn Near
54.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 44-46, from Medina

55.topics:
- Everything will pass away, except the face of God. (v. 26-27)[11]
   - Description of paradise. (v. 46-78)[12]

56.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 81 and 82, from Medina

58.topics:
- Divorce[8]
   - Faith and denial[8]
   - Hypocrisy[8]
   - The attitude believers should have toward non-believers.[8]

59.topics:
- The conflict between the Muslim community and the Jewish tribe of 
   Banu’n-Nadir of Medina.[8]

60.titleEnglish:
*She who is Examined* 

*aka*: The Examination, Affection

61.topics: - A call to unity between professed belief and actual behaviour.[8]

66.titleEnglish:
*Forbiddance* 

*aka*: Why do you Forbid?, The Forbidden, Chapter of the Prophet
66.topics: - Certain aspects of Muhammad’s personal and family life.[8]

67.titleArabic:
،*الملك* 

تبارك، تبارك الذي بيده الملك، المانع، المنجية
67.titleRomanization:
*Al-Mulk* 

*aka*: Tabarak, Tabarak Aladhee Biyedihi Al-Mulk, Al-Mani', Al-Munjiyya
67.titleEnglish:
*Dominion* 

*aka*: Blessed, Blessed is the One who Holds the Dominion, The Shield, The 
Savior
67.topics:
- Man’s inability to understand the mysteries of the universe, and his 
   dependence on guidance through divine revelation.[8]

68.revelationPhase: Early Mecca phase (610 - 618 AD). Except 17-33 and 48-50, from Medina

70.titleEnglish:
*The Ascending Ways* 

*aka*: The Impending Matters, Someone Asked
70.topics:
- The unwillingness to believe, caused by the restlessness inherent in 
   human nature.[8]

71.topics:
- The story of Noah.[8] 
      - The struggle against blind materialism and the lack of spiritual 
      values.[8]

73.revelationPhase: Early Mecca phase (610 - 618 AD). Except 10, 11 and 20, from Medina

74.topics:
- This short early surah outlines almost all fundamental Qur'anic 
   concepts.[8]

76.titleEnglish:
*The Human* 

*aka*: Hasn't There Come?, Endless Time, The Pious

77.revelationPhase: Middle Mecca phase (618 - 620 AD). Except 48, from Medina
77.topics: - The gradual revelation of the Qur'an.[8]

78.titleEnglish:
*The Tiding* 

*aka*: Rain Clouds, Questioning one Another
78.topics:
- Life after death.[8]
   - Resurrection and God’s ultimate judgment.[8]

79.titleEnglish:
*The Snatchers* 

*aka*: The Wide Expanse, The Calamity

80.titleEnglish:
*He Frowned* 

*aka*: The Piercing Cry, The Scribes

81.topics: - The Last Hour and man’s resurrection.[8]

93.topics:
- Man’s suffering and God’s justice.[8]
   - A message of hope and consolation is given to man from Allah's past 
   mercies.
   - Man is bidden to pursue the path of goodness and proclaim the bounties 
   of Allah.

95.topics: - A fundamental moral verity, common to all true religious teachings.[8]

96.topics: - The first five verses revealed to Muhammad. (v. 1-5) [8]

105.topics:
- The Abyssinian attack against Mecca in the year 570 CE, the Year of 
   the Elephant.[8]

106.topics:
- The Quraysh, custodians of the Kaaba, should be thankful to God for 
   protecting them from hunger and danger.[11]

107.revelationPhase: Early Mecca phase (610-618 AD). Only 1-3 from Mecca; the rest from Medina
107.topics:
- The meaning of true worship through sincere devotion and helping those 
   in need.[11]

108.topics:
- Spiritual riches through devotion and sacrifice.
   - Hatred results in the cutting off of all hope.[11]

109.topics: - The correct attitude towards those who reject faith.[11]

110.revelationPhase:
Medina phase (622 - 632 AD).Revealed at Mina on Last Hajj, but regarded as 
Medinan sura
110.topics: - The last complete surah revealed before Muhammad’s death.[8]

111.topics: - The hostility of Muhammad’s uncle Abu Lahab.[8]

112.titleArabic:
،*الإخلاص* 

المنفرة، النجاة، المعرفة، المذكرة، نور القرآن
112.titleRomanization:
*Al-Ikhlas* 

*aka*: Al-Munaffira, An-Najah, Al-Ma'rifa, Al-Mudhekira, Nur Al-Quran
112.titleEnglish:
*Sincerity* 

*aka*: Casting Away, Deliverance, Recognition, The Reminder, Light of the 
Quran

113.topics: - Seek refuge in God from evil of others.[11]

114.topics: - Trust in God's protection from temptations.[11]

#.revelationPhase: Note on Revelation Location and Period
